member.name: T:ic4.BufferPool
member.summary: The buffer pool allows allocating additional buffers for use by the program.

remarks.para: Most programs will only use buffers provided by one of the sink types. However, some programs require additional buffers, for example to use as destination for image processing.

To create additional buffers, first create a buffer pool by calling the constructor . Then, use to request a new buffer with a specified image type. Allocation options can be specified to customize the image buffer's memory alignment, pitch and total buffer size.
When an image buffer is no longer required, call on it. The image buffer will then be returned to the buffer pool.
The buffer pool has configurable caching behavior. By default, the buffer pool will cache one image buffer and return it the next time a matching image buffer is requested.
Image buffers objects created by the buffer pool are still valid after the buffer pool itself has been disposed.

member.name: M:ic4.BufferPool.#ctor(System.UInt64,System.Nullable{System.UInt64},ic4.IBufferAllocator)
member.summary: Create a new buffer pool, optionally specifying a caching behavior and a custom allocator.
member.param: Maximum number of frames to keep in the buffer pool's cache
Maximum size of the buffer pool cache in bytes, or null to not limit by size
The custom allocator to be used by the new buffer pool, or null to use the default allocator.

member.name: M:ic4.BufferPool.GetBuffer(ic4.ImageType,System.UInt32,System.Int32,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Requests a buffer from the buffer pool.
member.remarks: The buffer is either newly allocated, or retrieved from the buffer pool's buffer cache.
member.param: Image type of the requested buffer.

param.name: alignment
param.para: Specifies the alignment of the address of the buffer's memory.
Setting this to 0 lets the buffer pool select an alignment automatically.
The alignment must be a power of 2.

param.name: pitch
param.para: Specifies the pitch to use when allocating the buffer.
A value of 0 lets the buffer pool select a pitch automatically.
Setting a pitch that is smaller than the amount of memory required to store one line of image data will lead to an error.

param.name: bufferSize
param.para: Overrides the automatic buffer size calculation.
A value of 0 lets the buffer pool calculate the required buffer size automatically.
Setting a size that is smaller than the amount of memory required to store an image of a known format will lead to an error.

member.returns: The new image buffer

member.name: T:ic4.Grabber
member.summary: Represents an opened video capture device, allowing device configuration and stream setup.

remarks.para: The grabber object is the core component used when working with video capture devices.
Grabber objects are created using the constructor .

After creation, the most common operation on a grabber is to open a device. A device can be opened directly by
passing string identifying a device to
passing a object to
A device can also be selected and configured from a previously saved device state by
passing the file name of a device state file to
passing a byte array contains device state data to
passing a containing device state data to
To establish a data stream from the opened video capture device, call .
A is required if the program needs to access, process, or store image data. There are several sink types available to choose from, which are useful depending on the application, e.g. or .
A can be used to automatically display all images from the video capture device.
After the data stream has been set up, call to begin the transfer of images.
See Grabber States for a discussion of the internal states of the grabber object during its lifetime.

Some object references, e.g. , can keep the device and/or driver opened as long as they exist, since they point into device driver memory. To free all device-related resources, all objects references have to be released.

remarks.para: To restore the device state at a later time, use .

In addition to serializing the device's properties (like would), this function also saves the currently opened video capture device so that it can be re-opened at a later time with all settings restored.

member.name: M:ic4.Grabber.DeviceClose
member.summary: Closes the video capture device currently opened by this grabber instance
member.exception: The function was called from a thread that cannot perform the operation, e.g. a device callback.

remarks.para:
If the device is closed, all its resouces are released:
If image acquisition is active, it is stopped.
If a data stream was set up, it is stopped.
References to data stream-related objects are released, possibly destroying the sink and/or display.
Property objects retrieved from the become invalid.
objects and their memory stay allocated until they are disposed. References to image buffers can keep the video capture device open, if they point into driver memory.

member.name: P:ic4.Grabber.IsDeviceValid
member.summary: Checks whether the grabber's currently opened video capture device is ready to use.
member.value: true, if the grabber has an opened video capture device that is ready to use, otherwise false.

remarks.para:
There are multiple reasons for why this function may return false:
No device has been opened
The device was disconnected
There is a loose hardware connection
There was an internal error in the video capture device
There was a driver error
If the currently opened device becomes invalid, the event is raised.
See Grabber States for a discussion of the internal states of the grabber object during its lifetime.

member.summary: Represents an image buffer

remarks.para: Image buffer objects are created automatically by the various types. They can also be created manually on request by a , or by calling .
Programs use image buffers through objects of type . If the object is disposed, the image buffer is returned to its source for reuse. For example, an image buffer retrieved from will be re-queued.

member.summary: Creates an image buffer object using external memory as storage area for the image data.
member.param: Pointer to a region of memory to be used as image data by the image buffer object
Size of the region of memory pointed to by data
Difference between memory addresses of two consecutive lines of image data
Type of image to be stored in the image buffer
Function to be called when the image buffer is destroyed and the image data will no longer be accessed through it.
member.returns: The new image buffer object.

remarks.para:
This function can be useful when copying image data into buffers of third-party libraries:
Create an image object in the third-party library
Wrap the third-party library's image data into an image buffer using FromMemory.
Copy the data from an existing image buffer object into the third-party buffer using .
The program has to make sure that the memory pointed to by bufferPtr stays allocated as long as the image buffer object exists.
Calling on an image buffer returned by this function destroys the image buffer object, but does not free the associated memory.

member.name: P:ic4.ImageBuffer.Ptr
member.summary: Returns a pointer to the data managed by the image buffer.

value.para: A pointer to the image buffer's data.
The memory pointed to by the returned pointer is valid as long as the image buffer object exists.

member.value: The size of the image buffer

member.name: P:ic4.ImageBuffer.Pitch
member.summary: Returns the pitch for the image buffer.

value.para: The pitch of the image buffer.
The pitch is the distance between the starting memory location of two consecutive lines in bytes.

member.summary: Default behavior. Copy image data, meta data and chunk data.

member.summary: Instructs to skip the image data when copying.

remarks.para: If included in the flags argument, only copies the non-image parts of the buffer, and a program-defined algorithm can handle the image copy operation.

member.summary: Instructs to not copy the chunk data.

remarks.para: This can be useful if the chunk data is large and not required in the destination frame.

member.name: M:ic4.ImageBuffer.CopyFrom(ic4.ImageBuffer,ic4.ImageBuffer.CopyOptions)
member.summary: Copies the contents of one image buffer to another image buffer.
member.param: Source buffer to copy from
A bitwise combination of to customize the copy operation
member.exception: this is not writable. Check for details.

remarks.para: If the pixel format of the images in other and this is not equal, the image is converted. For example, if the pixel format of other is and the pixel format of this is , a demosaicing operation creates a color image.
If flags contains , the function does not copy the image data. The function then only copies the chunk data and meta data, and a program-defined algorithm can handle the image copy operation.
If flags contains , the function does not copy the chunk data contained in other. This can be useful if the chunk data is large and not required.
If the width or height of other and this are not equal, the function fails and throws an with the error code set to .
If there is no algorithm available for the requested conversion, the function fails and throws an with the error code set to .
If this is not writable, the function fails and throws an .

member.name: P:ic4.ImageBuffer.IsWritable
member.summary: Checks whether an image buffer object is (safely) writable.
member.value: true, if the image buffer not shared with any part of the library, and is therefore safely writable, otherwise false.

remarks.para: In some situations, image buffer objects are shared between the application holding a handle to the image buffer object and the library. For example, the image buffer might be shared with a display or a video writer.

A shared buffer is not safely writable. Writing to a buffer that is shared can lead to unexpected behavior, for example a modification may partially appear in the result of an operation that is happening in parallel.
Passing the image buffer into a function such as or can lead to a buffer becoming shared.

member.summary: Contains extension methods for that allow saving image buffer contents into files of various file formats.

example.para: Since the members are extension methods, they can be called both explicitly and on image buffers directly, as if they were member functions.
To call it as a member function, a using directive has to exist for the ic4 namespace:
Although not preferred, the function can also be called explicitly:

member.name: M:ic4.ImageBufferExtensions.SaveAsBitmap(ic4.ImageBuffer,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves an image buffer as a Bitmap file.
member.param: An image buffer
Path of the image file
If true, and the image buffer's pixel format is a bayer format, interpret the pixel data as monochrome and store the raw data as a monochrome image.
member.exception: buffer is null, or filename is null

remarks.para:
Depending on the pixel format of the image buffer, a transformation is applied before saving the image:
Monochrome pixel formats are converted to Mono8 and stored as a 8-bit monochrome bitmap file.
Bayer, RGB and YUV pixel formats are converted to BGR8 and stored as a 24-bit color bitmap file.

member.name: M:ic4.ImageBufferExtensions.SaveAsJpeg(ic4.ImageBuffer,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Saves an image buffer as a Jpeg file
member.param: An image buffer
Path of the image file

param.name: qualityPercent
param.para: Specifies the Jpeg image quality in percent.
High quality images will take more disk space, low quality images are smaller.

member.exception: buffer is null, or filename is null

remarks.para:
Depending on the pixel format of the image buffer, a transformation is applied before saving the image:
Monochrome pixel formats are converted to Mono8 and stored as a monochrome Jpeg file.
Bayer, RGB and YUV pixel formats are converted to BGR8 stored as a color Jpeg file.

member.name: M:ic4.ImageBufferExtensions.SaveAsPng(ic4.ImageBuffer,System.String,System.Boolean,ic4.PngCompressionLevel)
member.summary: Saves an image buffer as a PNG file.
member.param: An image buffer
Path of the image file
If true, and the image buffer's pixel format is a bayer format, interpret the pixel data as monochrome and store the raw data as a monochrome image.
Specifies the PNG compression level.
member.exception: buffer is null, or filename is null

remarks.para:
Depending on the pixel format of the image buffer, a transformation is applied before saving the image:
Monochrome pixel formats with a bit depth higher than 8bpp are converted to Mono16 and stored as a monochrome PNG file with 16 bits per channel.
Mono8 image buffers are stored as a monochrome PNG file with 8 bits per channel.
Bayer format with a bit depth higher than 8bpp are converted to BGRa16 and stored as a 4-channel PNG with 16 bits per channel.
8-bit Bayer, RGB and YUV pixel formats are converted to BGR8 stored as a 3-channel PNG file with 8 bits per channel.

member.name: M:ic4.ImageBufferExtensions.SaveAsTiff(ic4.ImageBuffer,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves an image buffer as a Tiff file.
member.param: An image buffer
Path of the image file
If true, and the image buffer's pixel format is a bayer format, interpret the pixel data as monochrome and store the raw data as a monochrome image.
member.exception: buffer is null, or filename is null

remarks.para:
Depending on the pixel format of the image buffer, a transformation is applied before saving the image:
Monochrome pixel formats with a bit depth higher than 8bpp are converted to Mono16 and stored as a monochrome Tiff file with 16 bits per channel.
Mono8 image buffers are stored as a monochrome Tiff file with 8 bits per channel.
Bayer formats with a bit depth higher than 8bpp are converted to BGRa16 and stored as a 4-channel Tiff file with 16 bits per channel.
8-bit Bayer, RGB and YUV pixel formats are converted to BGR8 stored as a 3-channel Tiff file with 8 bits per channel.

member.name: T:ic4.PropCategory
member.summary: Category properties define a tree-relationship between all properties in a property map.

remarks.para: The root of the tree is always the category property with the name Root.
To find which properties are linked from a category, use the property.

Categories can contain other categories recursively. A very simple category tree might look like this:
Root (category)
AcquisitionControl (category)
AcquisitionStart (command)
AcquisitionStop (command)
AcquisitionFrameRate (float)
ImageFormatControl (category)
Width (integer)
Height (integer)
PropCategory instances are created in multiple ways:

list.item: By directly querying a for a category property:
By casting a object obtained from one of the functions returning generic property objects:

member.value: An enumeration of the properties contained in the category

member.name: T:ic4.Property
member.summary: Represents a property of a component, usually a video capture device.

remarks.para: All property types are derived from Property, e.g. , or .
is also derived from Property, even though they are not part of the category tree. Nevertheless, enumeration entries support all standard property operations.

Property objects and objects of classes derived from Property are created in multiple ways:
By passing the name of a known property to or one of its typed sibling functions like ,
By passing a property identifier to or one of its overloads,
By enumerating to get all properties from a category,
By enumerating to get all properties in a property map's category tree,
By enumerating to get all entries of an enumeration property,
By enumerating to get the properties selected by a property.
Property objects hold a reference to an internal library object. To release the reference, call .
Property objects become invalid after the device has been closed, and will throw an exception if used afterwards.

member.value: Visibility hint for the property.

member.name: P:ic4.Property.IsLocked
member.summary: Indicates whether the property is currently locked.
member.value: true, if the property is currently locked, otherwise false

remarks.para: A locked property can be read, but attempts to write its value will fail.
A property's locked status may change upon writing to another property.
Common examples for locked properties are ExposureTime or Gain if ExposureAuto or GainAuto are enabled.

member.name: P:ic4.Property.IsLikelyLockedByStream
member.summary: Tries to determine whether a property is locked because a data stream is active.
member.value: true, if the property is currently locked, and will likely be unlocked if the data stream is stopped. false, if the property is not currently locked, or stopping the data stream will probably not lead to the property being unlocked.
member.remarks: For technical reasons, this function cannot always accurately predict the future.

member.name: P:ic4.Property.IsAvailable
member.summary: Indicates whether the property is currently available.
member.value: true, if the property is currently available, otherwise false

remarks.para: If a property is not available, attempts to read or write its value will fail.
A property may become unavailable, if its value does not have a meaning in the current state of the device. The property's availability status can change upon writing to another property.

member.name: P:ic4.Property.IsReadonly
member.summary: Indicates whether the whether a property is read-only.
member.value: true, if the property is read-only, otherwise false

remarks.para: A read-only property will never be writable, the read-only status will never change.
A Common examples for a read-only property is DeviceTemperature.

member.name: P:ic4.Property.IsSelector
member.summary: Indicates whether this property's value changes the meaning and/or value of other properties.
member.value: true, if the property is a selector, otherwise false

member.remarks: Using -derived property identifiers allows typed access to property objects, e.g.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionBurstFrameCount
member.summary: Number of frames to acquire for each trigger.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionBurstInterval
member.summary: Minimum interval between frames in an acquisition burst.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionFrameRate
member.summary: Controls the acquisition rate at which the frames are captured.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionMode
member.summary: Sets the acquisition mode of the device. It defines mainly the number of frames to capture during an acquisition and the way the acquisition stops.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionStart
member.summary: Starts the Acquisition of the device. The number of frames captured is specified by AcquisitionMode.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.AcquisitionStop
member.summary: Stops the Acquisition of the device at the end of the current Frame. It is mainly used when AcquisitionMode is Continuous but can be used in any acquisition mode.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionDeviceKey
member.summary: Provides the device key that allows the device to check the validity of action commands. The device internal assertion of an action signal is only authorized if the ActionDeviceKey and the action device key value in the protocol message are equal.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionGroupKey
member.summary: Provides the key that the device will use to validate the action on reception of the action protocol message.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionGroupMask
member.summary: Provides the mask that the device will use to validate the action on reception of the action protocol message.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionQueueSize
member.summary: Indicates the size of the scheduled action commands queue. This number represents the maximum number of scheduled action commands that can be pending at a given point in time.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSchedulerCancel
member.summary: Cancels all scheduled actions.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSchedulerCommit
member.summary: Schedules the action to be executed time specified by ActionSchedulerTime, with optional repetition in intervals of ActionSchedulerInterval.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSchedulerInterval
member.summary: Action repetition interval. A value of 0 schedules the action to be executed only once.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSchedulerStatus
member.summary: Indicates whether there are actions scheduled.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSchedulerTime
member.summary: Camera time for when the action is to be scheduled.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.ActionSelector
member.summary: Selects to which Action Signal further Action settings apply.

member.summary: Controls ratio of the selected color component to a reference color component. It is used for white balancing.

member.summary: This enumeration selects a balance ratio control to configuration. Once a balance ratio control has been selected, all changes to the balance ratio settings will be applied to the selected control.

member.summary: Controls the mode for automatic white balancing between the color channels. The white balancing ratios are automatically adjusted.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.BinningHorizontal
member.summary: Number of horizontal photo-sensitive cells to combine together. This increases the intensity (or signal to noise ratio) of the pixels and reduces the horizontal resolution (width) of the image. A value of 1 indicates that no horizontal binning is performed by the camera.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.BinningVertical
member.summary: Number of vertical photo-sensitive cells to combine together. This increases the intensity (or signal to noise ratio) of the pixels and reduces the vertical resolution (height) of the image. A value of 1 indicates that no vertical binning is performed by the camera.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.BlackLevel
member.summary: Controls the analog black level as an absolute physical value. This represents a DC offset applied to the video signal

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerMask
member.summary: Specifies the time for which trigger pulses are ignored after accepting a trigger signal.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerMode
member.summary: Controls if the selected trigger is active.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerOperation
member.summary: Controls the operation mode of the sensor in trigger mode.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerOverlap
member.summary: Specifies the type trigger overlap permitted with the previous frame. This defines when a valid trigger will be accepted for a new frame.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerSelector
member.summary: Selects the type of trigger to configure.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerSoftware
member.summary: Generates an internal trigger. TriggerSource must be set to Software or Any.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.TriggerSource
member.summary: Specifies the internal signal or physical input Line to use as the trigger source.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.UserSetDefault
member.summary: Selects the feature User Set to load and make active by default when the device is reset.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.UserSetLoad
member.summary: Loads the User Set specified by UserSetSelector to the device and makes it active.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.UserSetSave
member.summary: Save the User Set specified by UserSetSelector to the non-volatile memory of the device.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.UserSetSelector
member.summary: Selects the feature User Set to load, save or configure.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.Width
member.summary: Width of the image provided by the device (in pixels).

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.WidthMax
member.summary: Maximum width of the image (in pixels). The dimension is calculated after horizontal binning, decimation or any other function changing the horizontal dimension of the image.

member.name: F:ic4.PropId.Zoom
member.summary: Changes the zoom setting of the lens.

member.name: T:ic4.PropertyMap
member.summary: Represents the property interface of a component, usually a video capture device.

remarks.para: A property map offers quick access to known properties as well as functions to enumerate all features through the category tree.

There is a plethora of overloaded functions to access properties with a known name and type. For example, to find a known integer property, use:
To find a property with a known name, but unknown type, use one of the untyped functions:
Property values for known properties can also be set directly, for example by calling:
To get a flat list of all properties in the property map's category tree, enumerate .
The current values of all properties in a property map can be saved to a file or a memory buffer using or one of its overloads. To restore the settings at a later time, call .
An image buffer containing chunk data can be connected to a property map using . Doing so lets the property map uses the image buffer as the data source for chunk property read operations.

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.ExecuteCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a command with a known name.
member.param: Name of a command in this property map

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.ExecuteCommand(ic4.PropIdCommand)
member.summary: Executes a command with a specified identifier.
member.param: Identifier of a command in this property map

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.SetValue(System.String,System.Int64)
member.summary: Set the value of a property with a known name to the passed integer value.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
New value to be set

remarks.para:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For integer properties, the value is set directly.
For float properties, the value is set directly.
For boolean properties, if the value is 1 or 0, it is set to true or false respectively. Other values result in an error.
For enumeration properties, the value is set directly.
For command properties, the command is executed if the value is 1.
For all other property types, the call results in an error.

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.SetValue(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Set the value of a property with a known name to the passed double value.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
New value to be set

remarks.para:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For integer properties, the value is rounded to the nearest integer.
For float properties, the value is set directly.
For all other property types, the call results in an error.

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.SetValue(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set the value of a property with a known name to the passed bool value.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
New value to be set

remarks.para:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For boolean properties, the value is set directly.
For enumeration properties, it selects the entry with a name that unambiguously suggests to represent true or false, if available.
For command properties, the command is executed if value is true.
For all other property types, the call results in an error.

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.SetValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Set the value of a property with a known name to the passed string value.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
New value to be set
member.exception: propName is null or value is null.

remarks.para:
The behavior depends on the type of property:
For integer properties, the string is parsed, and the found integer value is set.
For float properties, the string is parsed, and the found floating-point value is set.
For boolean properties, a value is set if the string can be unambiguously identified to represent true or false.
For enumeration properties, the entry with a naming matching the value is set.
For string properties, the value is set directly.
For command properties, the command is executed if value is "1", "true" or "execute".
For all other property types, the call results in an error.

member.param: Identifier of an integer property in this property map
New value to be set

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.GetValueLong(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a property with a known name interpreted as an integer.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
member.returns: The value of the property interpreted as an integer.
member.remarks:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For integer properties, the value is returned directly.
For boolean properties, the value returned is 1 or 0.
For all other property types, the call results in an error. ( with set to .)

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.GetValueDouble(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a property with a known name interpreted as a double.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
member.returns: The value of the property interpreted as a double.
member.remarks:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For float properties, the value is returned directly.
For integer properties, the value is converted to double.
For all other property types, the call results in an error. ( with set to .)

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.GetValueBool(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a property with a known name interpreted as a bool.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
member.returns: The value of the property interpreted as a bool.
member.remarks:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For boolean properties, the value is returned directly.
For enumeration properties, a value is returned if the name of the currently selected entry unambiguously suggests to represent true or false.
For all other property types, the call results in an error. ( with set to .)

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.GetValueString(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a property with a known name interpreted as a string.
member.param: Name of a property in this property map
member.returns: The value of the property interpreted as a string.
member.remarks:
The behavior depends on the type of the property:
For integer properties, the value is converted to a string.
For float properties, the value is converted to a string.
For boolean properties, the returned value is "true" or "false".
For enumeration properties, the name of the currently selected entry is returned.
For string properties, the value is returned directly.
For all other property types, the call results in an error. ( with set to .)

member.name: M:ic4.PropertyMap.ConnectChunkData(ic4.ImageBuffer)
member.summary: Enables the use of the chunk data in the passed as a backend for chunk properties in the property map.
member.param: An image buffer with chunk data. This parameter may be null to disconnect the previously connected buffer.

remarks.para: The property map takes a reference to the passed image buffer, extending its lifetime and preventing automatic reuse. The reference is released when a new image buffer is connected to the property map, or null is passed in the buffer argument.

member.name: T:ic4.QueueSink
member.summary: A sink implementation that allows a program to process all images received from a video capture device

remarks.para:
A queue sink manages a number of buffers that are organized in two queues:
A free queue that buffers are pulled from to fill with data from the device
An output queue that contains the filled buffers ready to be picked up by the program
Pass the sink to or to feed images into the sink.

Usually, the sink is interacted with by registering handlers for the sink's events. The Events are raised at different significant points in the lifetime of a queue sink:
occurs when a data stream is being set up from the device to the sink. The event handler is responsible for making sure there are enough buffers queued for streaming to begin.
occurs whenever there are images available in the output queue.
occurs when a previously-created data stream is stopped.

To retrieve the oldest available image from the output queue, call or . The returned image buffer is owned by the program. If the program no longer needs the image buffer, must be called it to return the image buffer to the sink's free queue.

A program does not necessarily have to requeue all image buffers immediately; it can choose keep references to the a number of them in its own data structures. However, please note that if there are no buffers in the free queue when the device tries to deliver a frame, the frame will be dropped. Use to find out whether a buffer underrun occurred.

member.name: E:ic4.QueueSink.SinkConnected
member.summary: Occurs when the data stream to the sink is created

remarks.para: The event handler can abort the creation of the data stream by setting to true.

indicates the minimum number of buffers required for the data stream to operate. If the event handler does not allocate any buffers, the sink will automatically allocate the minimum number of buffers required.
The function is executed on the thread that calls .

member.name: E:ic4.QueueSink.FramesQueued
member.summary: Occurs when new images were added to the sink's queue of filled buffers.

remarks.para: The event handler usually calls to get access to the filled image buffers.
If this callback function performs a lengthy operation, it is recommended to regularly check to determine whether the data stream is being stopped.
The function is executed on dedicated thread managed by the sink.

When the data stream to the sink is stopped, the call will wait until this event handler returns. This can quickly lead to a deadlock, if code in the event handler performs an operation that unconditionally requires activity on the thread that called .

member.name: E:ic4.QueueSink.SinkDisconnected
member.summary: Occurs when the data stream to the sink is stopped.

remarks.para: The function is executed on the thread that calls .

member.name: M:ic4.QueueSink.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{ic4.PixelFormat},ic4.IBufferAllocator,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new queue sink.

param.name: acceptedPixelFormats
param.para: An optional list of pixel formats that restrict the input to this sink.
This can be used to force an automatic conversion from the device's pixel format to a pixel format usable by the sink.

param.name: customAllocator
param.para: An optional custom buffer allocator

param.name: maxOutputBuffers
param.para: Defines the maximum number of buffers that are stored in the sink's output queue.
If set to 0, the number of buffers is unlimited.
If a new frame arrives at the sink, and the output queue size would exceed this number, the oldest image is discarded and its buffer is added to the free queue.

member.name: M:ic4.QueueSink.PopOutputBuffer

summary.para: Retrieves a buffer that was filled with image data from the sink's output queue.

member.returns: A filled image buffer

remarks.para: This operation is only valid while the sink is connected to a device in a data stream.
The buffers are retrieved in order they were received from the video capture device; the oldest image is returned first.
After a successfull call, the program owns the image buffer through the reference. The image buffer object must be disposed to put the image buffer into the sink's free queue for later reuse.

member.name: T:ic4.Sink
member.summary: Abstract base class for sinks.

remarks.para: Sink objects provide programmatic access to the image data acquired from video capture devices.

There are multiple sink types available:
A is recommended when a program needs to process all or most images received from the device.
A can be used to capture images or short image sequences on demand.
To create a sink object, use its constructor, e.g. or .
A sink is connected to a video capture device using or one of its overloads.

member.name: T:ic4.SnapSink
member.summary: The snap sink is a sink implementation that allows a program to capture single images or sequences of images on demand, while still having a display showing all images.

remarks.para: To create a snap sink, use .
Pass the sink to or to feed images into the sink.
To grab a single image out of the stream, call . To grab a sequence of images, call .

The snap sink manages the buffers used for background image aquisition as well as for the grabbed images. During stream setup, a number of buffers is allocated depending on the configured allocation strategy. Additional buffers can be automatically created on demand, if the allocation strategy allows. Likewise, if there is a surplus of unused image buffers, unused buffers are reclaimed and released automatically.

Image buffers that were returned by one of the snap functions are owned by their respective caller through the reference to the . To return the image buffer to the sink for reuse, call on the image buffer.
Please note that if there are no buffers available in the sink when the device tries to deliver a frame, the frame will be dropped. Use to find out whether a buffer underrun occurred.

By default, the sink uses buffers provided by the device driver or the implicitly created transformation filter. It is possible to use program-defined buffers be used by providing a to the sink constructor.

member.name: M:ic4.SnapSink.SnapSingle(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Grabs a single image out of the video stream received from the video capture device.
member.param: Time to wait for a new image to arrive
member.returns: A filled image buffer
member.exception: No image was received before the timeout elapsed.

remarks.para: This operation is only valid while the sink is connected to a device in a data stream.
After a successfull call, the program owns the image buffer through the reference. The image buffer object must be disposed to put the image buffer into the sink's free queue for later reuse.

If the image buffer object is not disposed, their finalizer will also return the image buffer to the sink. However, it is recommended to always manually dispose the image buffer for deterministic behavior.

member.exception: No images were received before the timeout elapsed.

remarks.para: This operation is only valid while the sink is connected to a device in a data stream.
After a successfull call, the program owns the image buffers through the references. The image buffer objects must be disposed to put the image buffer into the sink's free queue for later reuse.

If the image buffer objects are not disposed, their finalizer will also return the image buffers to the sink. However, it is recommended to always manually dispose the image buffers for deterministic behavior.

member.name: T:ic4.SnapSinkAllocationStrategy
member.summary: The buffer allocation strategy defines how many buffers are pre-allocated, when additional buffers are created, and when excess buffers are reclaimed.

member.summary: Defines the number of buffers to auto-allocate when the stream is set up.

summary.para: Defines the minimum number of required free buffers.
If the number of free buffers falls below this, new buffers are allocated.

value.para: The minimum number of required free buffers.

member.name: P:ic4.SnapSinkAllocationStrategy.NumBuffersFreeThreshold

summary.para: Defines the maximum number of free buffers
If the number of free buffers grows above this, buffers are freed.
If set to 0, buffers are not freed automatically.

member.value: The maximum number of free buffers
member.remarks: If NumBuffersFreeThreshold is not 0, it must be larger than + 2.

member.name: P:ic4.SnapSinkAllocationStrategy.NumBuffersMax

summary.para: Defines the maximum total number of buffers this sink will allocate.
This includes both free buffers managed by the sink and filled buffers owned by the program.

member.value: The maximum total number of buffers this sink will allocate
member.remarks: If set to 0, there is no limit to the total number of buffers.

member.name: M:ic4.VideoWriter.AddFrame(ic4.ImageBuffer)
member.summary: Adds an image to the currently open video file.
member.param: Image buffer to be added to the video file

remarks.para: must be called before adding images to the video file.
The image buffer's must be equal to the imageType parameter passed to when starting the file.

The video writer can retain a reference to the image buffer. This can delay the release and possible reuse of the image buffer. In this case, the buffer becomes shared, and is no longer safely writable (). Use to always let the video writer immediately copy the data out of the image buffer.

member.name: M:ic4.VideoWriter.AddFrameCopy(ic4.ImageBuffer)
member.summary: Adds an image to the currently open video file, copying the image data in the process.
member.param: Image buffer to be added to the video file

remarks.para: must be called before adding images to the video file.
The image buffer's must be equal to the imageType parameter passed to when starting the file.

The image buffer's contents will be copied, so that the buffer's reference count is not increased and it can be reused immedietely if the final reference is released. Use to avoid the copy operation if it is not necessary.
